articles.title: After Trump verdict, Manhattan District Attorney says 'I did my job...the jury has spoken'
articles.description: After Donald Trump was found guilty on all 34 felony counts in his criminal hush money trial, Manhattan District Attorney Alvin Bragg said "the only voice that matters is the voice of the jury and the jury has spoken."
articles.content:

articles.author: The Australian Financial Review
articles.title: Donald Trump becomes America’s first felon president
articles.description: The conviction — a humiliating defeat for a man who has dwelled in legal gray zones for decades — brings America’s highest office to a new low.
articles.content: But in closing arguments, a prosecutor noted that Cohen had told his lies for Trump. “We didn’t choose Michael Cohen to be our witness; we didn’t pick him up at the witness store,” said the prosecutor, Joshua Steinglass, adding that the former presid... [13517 chars]

articles.author: Quartz India
articles.title: Donald Trump convicted in New York hush money trial
articles.description: The former president was found guilty on all counts in his New York hush money trial
articles.content: Jurors found Donald Trump guilty on 34 counts in the former President’s hush money trial in New York on Thursday, according to The New York Times. He is the first American president to become a felon. The 12 Manhattan residents who sit on the jury re... [3629 chars]

articles.author: The Guardian
articles.title: Trump guilty on all counts - so what happens next?
articles.description: On a historic night for American politics, Jonathan Freedland and Sam Levine look at what the verdict will mean – both for Trump himself, and for the election in November
articles.content: Donald Trump has made history again, becoming the first US president, sitting or former, to be a convicted criminal. Late on Thursday a New York jury found him guilty on all 34 counts of falsifying records to cover up a sex scandal. Within minutes of... [277 chars]

articles.title: Trump's Trial and Conviction: A Historic Legal Battle
articles.description: The outlines of legal woes facing Donald Trump continue as a New York jury convicts him of falsifying records to hide a payment to a porn star. Despite the criminal conviction, Trump's campaign for the presidency remains unaffected. Meanwhile, significant financial backing emerges from Republican mega donor Miriam Adelson.

articles.author: The Guardian
articles.title: Trump’s conviction on all 34 counts is a full-blown victory for DA Alvin Bragg
articles.description: Prosecutors took a case that was about boring paper crimes and successfully turned it into one that was about something simple: lying
articles.content: Donald Trump’s conviction on all 34 felony counts on Thursday marked a full-blown victory for Alvin Bragg, the first term Manhattan district attorney who was criticized for using a novel legal strategy to bring a historic criminal case against a form... [5744 chars]

articles.author: Devdiscourse
articles.title: Trump's Conviction Ignites Donor Surge Ahead of 2024 Election
articles.description: Top Republican donors, despite Donald Trump's recent conviction, have ramped up their financial support for his 2024 presidential campaign. Many view the legal actions against Trump as politically motivated, encouraging significant donations from key figures. This trend underscores Trump's sustained donor backing, potentially boosting his chances against President Joe Biden.
articles.content: Major Republican donors said on Thursday they were willing to back the first convicted felon running for U.S. president, with at least one giving money to Donald Trump for the first time, according to around a dozen benefactors and fundraisers. Many ... [4232 chars]

articles.title: Former president will seek to turn verdict into campaign fuel
articles.description: Donald Trump will try to capitalise on what might otherwise be a career-ending judgment in his election bid, claiming he is the victim of a political witchhunt.
articles.content:
New York | Donald Trump will seek to turn a historic verdict into fuel for his election campaign, after he was found guilty of falsifying records to cover up a sex scandal, making him the first former US president convicted of a crime.

articles.title: Can Trump come to Canada after felony conviction?
articles.description: A Canadian immigration lawyer says now that Donald Trump is a convicted felon, he is technically barred from crossing the border into Canada.
articles.content:
Laura Osman, The Canadian Press
OTTAWA -- A Canadian immigration lawyer says now that Donald Trump is a convicted felon, he is technically barred from crossing the border into Canada.

articles.author: Devdiscourse
articles.title: Trump's Conviction: Legal Battles Ahead for Ex-President
articles.description: Donald Trump, the first former U.S. president convicted of a crime, remains free while awaiting sentencing for falsifying business records. Unlikely to serve prison time, Trump could face fines or probation. As he plans to appeal, the road ahead includes sentencing, potential home confinement, and possible political run against Joe Biden.
articles.content: Donald Trump, the first former U.S. president to be convicted of a crime, will remain a free man while he awaits sentencing and could avoid a prison term entirely for falsifying business records to cover up a hush money payment to a porn star. Here i... [2784 chars]

articles.author: Devdiscourse
articles.title: Trump's Historic Conviction: Impacts and Reactions
articles.description: Donald Trump became the first U.S. president to be convicted of a crime, found guilty on 34 counts of falsifying documents to cover up hush money payments. This historic verdict has implications for the 2024 presidential election and has led to mixed reactions regarding its impact on markets and democracy.
articles.content:
Donald Trump became the first U.S. president to be convicted of a crime on Thursday when a New York jury found him guilty of falsifying documents to cover up a payment to silence a porn star ahead of the 2016 election.
